Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant-Trade and Social Boundaries During the Late Neolithic on the Great Hungarian Plain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social and cultural boundaries are highly contested and constantly changing. They do not always correlate with political boundaries (e.g., the social boundaries of former Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Hungary, and Romania often cross-cut political demarcations), thus making the study of early social boundaries imperative for scholars to understand the modern developments in the region. With the support of her advisor, Dr. William Parkinson, graduate student Danielle Riebe will conduct research on the relationship between boundaries and interaction during the Late Neolithic (5000-4500 BCE) on the Great Hungarian Plain. Archaeologists often cite interactions between people as a trigger for emergent social complexity as seen through the dissemination of ideas and technology and the spread of agriculture and animal domestication. The Plain offers an ideal location to investigate how interaction, specifically trade, impacts the formation, alteration, and destruction of social and cultural boundaries by focusing on two archaeologically defined groups, the Tisza and Herp√°ly.

In an area that is environmentally homogenous, these groups emerged in the archaeological record at the beginning of the Late Neolithic and are differentiated by very distinct material culture, including ceramics and chipped-stone tools. As people trade these materials, their ideas, traditions, techniques, and social practices are diffused at the same time. Analytical techniques, including laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS), will be used to assess the composition of ceramic and chipped-stone material in order to model raw material provenience in relation to depositional context. By analyzing how objects are created, where they are constructed, and how they are circulated after production, Ms. Riebe will explore how communities on the Plain differentiated themselves and their neighbors.

In addition to investigating theoretical issues concerning the role of interaction in social developments, this project also makes intellectual contributions to the field of anthropology by challenging how cultural boundaries are delineated. Traditionally, boundaries are demarcated based on the identification of similar or dissimilar cultural material. However, this simplistic approach does not account for how boundaries persist in spite of trade, suggesting that more attention be given to the reconstruction of interactions between peoples in order to understand the relationship between regional interactions and the process of boundary formation.

This dissertation will contribute to a broader impact by promoting international collaboration between U.S. and Hungarian citizens and scholars, in the study of prehistoric boundaries and social change. Findings will be made available to academics and the public through public lectures, presentations at conferences, peer-reviewed articles and a monograph. All of the findings and interpretations from this project will be included in Ms. Riebe's dissertation, and copies of the dissertation will be provided to all participating institutions. Funding for this project will allow Ms. Riebe to utilize the skills and experiences that she has acquired during her academic training to produce a dissertation that is both anthropologically illuminating and progressive, and that advances the field of anthropology, our knowledge of prehistoric Eastern Europe, and our understanding of socio-political developments in the modern world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the relationship between interaction and socio-cultural boundaries during the Late Neolithic (5000-4500 BCE) on the Great Hungarian Plain. Interactions in both the past and present are the way in which ideas, beliefs, innovations, and materials are transmitted and consequently, also challenge the way that people identify themselves and others. In Eastern Europe, as well as in many other parts of the world, political boundaries and cultural/ethnic boundaries do not always correspond resulting in continual social interactions and the constant re-negotiation of socio-cultural boundaries. Often times material culture is used as social identifiers – with examples like wedding rings, burkas, sports paraphernalia, Louis Vuitton shoes, a Star of David necklace, etc. Just as people today use material culture as identifiers to help signal and reinforce different beliefs, social or cultural statuses, ethnic backgrounds (i.e. different social boundaries), this project sought to reconstruct ancient cultural boundaries by assessing the material culture and in turn, model the extent to which peoples interacted in the past in order to ascertain the degree of connectivity between Late Neolithic sites on the Plain.

Summary of project outcomes. Between April 2013 and January 2015, the NSF DDIG funds were used to conduct a multi-phase doctoral project. In the spring of 2013, surface survey and collection was carried out at two previously unexcavated archaeological sites. The summer of 2013 was spent traveling to several museums throughout Hungary to inventory ceramic materials from seven previously excavated Late Neolithic sites. Ceramic materials from both the surveyed and excavated sites were stylistically assessed and all information was recorded in an electronic database. By September 2013 over 60,000 sherds had been analyzed and entered into the database. A selected number of ceramics (n = 510) were selected for LA-ICP-MS analysis and samples of the sherds were transported to the Elemental Analysis Facility at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, IL. The compositional analysis was conducted between September 2013 and September 2014 in order to identify locally made sherds versus imported sherds and model short-distance trade and interaction. In addition to the ceramic analysis, during the summer of 2013 I also inventoried and assessed the worked stone tool assemblages from six sites in order to model long-distance trade and interaction. The resulting database contains records for over 600 lithics. In December 2014, I returned to Hungary with a p-XRF device and analyzed the obsidian lithics from six sites in order to precisely identify where the materials were coming from and to model how they were traded across the Plain.

Intellectual merit. This project has challenged the notion of how archaeological cultures can and should be investigated. Instead of viewing past cultures as stagnant entities, this project encouraged an active perspective focusing on how interactions can be used to delineate cultural boundaries. By assessing the Late Neolithic materials from a number of sites across the Great Hungarian Plain, I have been able to model long-distance and short-distance interactions and the degree of connectivity between sites, which can then be used to infer socio-cultural boundaries in the past and changes in those boundaries over time and space. The basic principals of this research are cross-culturally applicable and have the potential to significantly advance the field of anthropology – and in particular to understand how critical interactions have been and will continue to be in shaping societies around the world.
